review_title: Good work with lots of pros and a couple cons
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Biggest perk was flexibility. As long as you get your research done and attend relevant meetings, you have a lot of flexibility to self-schedule your work. Another was that my lab had great tools and workspaces. My advisor was very helpful and nice to work with.
cons: The office I was given was tiny and had no windows. Academic research can at times be pretty frustrating and stressful, especially when your work is hitting dead ends and you haven't had a good breakthrough in a while.

pros: The Keeweenaw peninsula is beautiful.
cons:
The professors are incredibly sexist and demeaning towards women. If you try to report them, you’ll just end up with a bunch of BS about how they are building multi million dollar women’s facilities on campus. They will come up with a way to kick you out or force you to leave if you speak up. All of the women are afraid to talk to each other, to be seen together because of this. They are all afraid of being forced out with no way to fight it.

The insurance is horrible. I ended up having to take out a loan to have an MRI done.

If you don’t have a male appendage, stay away from this institution.

review_title: Tougher for staff, women, and non-engineers
job_title: Marketing and Outreach Specialist in Houghton, MI
pros:
If your brain fits at Michigan Tech, it can be a fantastic place. My partner's on the faculty in a STEM field, and it's been amazing for him. There's a kind of joy on campus having this many nerds in one place - I'll always remember the time I walked into Walmart and overheard "EVERY idiot knows [insert differential equation talk here.]"

 Tech's smaller size means more opportunities for collaboration and (sometimes) less red tape. It also makes the administration seem more accessible - I've worked at larger universities, and I wouldn't think to refer to the upper-level administration by first name. Not out of formality, just unfamiliarity. At Tech, Rick calls Jackie to figure out how to fill Bonnie's retirement vacancy.

The snow's a pro and a con. If you like getting outside, there are infinite places to explore. I've gotten in better shape since we moved here, since I picked up cross country skiing as something to do.
cons:
The downside of the smaller size can mean tendencies towards cliques, and university-wide decisions being made with little transparency and not much permanence. It's hard to love a large committee, but you miss them after the tenth "well, [X and Y names] decided [drastic policy change], so now we have to scramble." 

It's common for decisions and promotions to be made based on personal relationships. If you're connected to that upper-level club, you'll be fine. If you're a local and know the backstory of half of the employees, you'll also probably be fine. If you're on your own, you're on your own. Women and minorities may face problems that are hard to put your finger on, but just...don't feel right. Missed promotions, people talking over you in meetings, less lab space, and additional work without recognition or reward.

And the downside of the snow. The airport only flies out successfully about 50% of the time in the winter. The days in February and March can be very long, grey, and cold.

pros: Everyone is very nice and friendly.

review_title: Flexible, independent work in soft-money research
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ann Arbor, MI
pros: The experience varies depending on which division you work for and who your bosses are but, generally, you can create a flexible schedule and have a lot of independence to pursue whatever professional development you need in order to execute research. People are generally very friendly and the offices are quite nice.
cons:
It can be quite mercenary, as your salary is derived entirely from outside funding sources. When funding is tight (e.g., government grants dry up, MTRI is less successful in winning grants), they have to let people go. Sometimes, they don't let the right people go. This is often when the decision is driven by politics or a search for someone to blame. Principal Investigators (PIs) are usually never driven off; it is often junior employees that are let go, even though the junior employee might have more technical skills and experience than a PI who simply isn't very competitive for grants. 

For women, in particular the skewed gender balance can make for a difficult workplace. The established female PIs have been less-than-supportive toward new women in the workplace.

review_title: Great leadership experience for student employees
pros: This job provided me with fantastic leadership experience and helped me a lot with my confidence in managing multiple aspects of a business. It required a lot of coordination between four different departments on campus and placed a great deal of responsibility on my shoulders, and I loved the challenges it brought. An outstanding job opportunity for students who want to shave a few grand worth of room and board off their tuition bills.
cons: I was a higher level student staff member and shortly after starting work there the disconnect and unfriendly politics between departments became really obvious. Can't say much, but there was a lot of drama and it seemed at times that my supervisor should've been someone from a different department because my work was more related to them than it was to the boss I actually had, to the point where I received conflicting direction from multiple departments.

pros:
1. less distraction: remote location ensures less reasons to waste time!
2. above average undergraduate student quality and teaching: strong emphasis is placed on training and preparing undergraduates for focused industry jobs
3. active lifestyle: despite severe winters, there are plenty of opportunities for year-round outdoor activities
cons:
1. poor talent recognition mechanisms: instead of focusing on number of publication, there should be more focus on quality of publication, there should be special emphasis on recognition among peers
2. below average graduate student quality: bar for admission should be raised across each department and within the departments
3. remote location: commuting is a big problem due to weather and cost, lack of opportunities for souse's job and cultural exposure

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Beaverton, OR
pros: GRA in the physics department. I have only great things to say about that department. Very well run, I've heard drama about other departments and ours has none. Incredibly knowledgeable and brilliant professors who almost all have an open door policy. A lot of good opportunity for collaboration within the department. The department head is really great. He really pushes for student success.
cons: It's a lot of work, there is an expectation to work after hours and weekends. But I think this is being a grad student anywhere. Sometimes there are some issues with payroll and some paperwork type of things but these are always outside of the department.

job_title: Assistant Photo Editor in Houghton, MI
pros: While a student, working at Michigan Tech is extremely rewarding. Not only do you get experience working in your industry prior to graduation, but you gain professional references that are good anywhere--something hard to find in the area.
cons: There is no room for advancement, not even the opportunity. It is rare that a student is offered a permanent position upon graduation as most of your work is under someone else, thus discrediting a lot of your work. Most work done in Marketing and Communications, for example, is property of the school and cannot be used in portfolios or resumes.

review_title: Great experience at school, and in community.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Great atmosphere for learning and working.  No limit was put on what we could work on or try to do.  Most people were very good to work with and were like minded in educational values and desire for excellence.  Can follow my research goals and achieve them with advice and mentoring from my advisor.  Good balance between work, school, and fun.
cons: Some employees skate through their daily work, and should be replaced with more enthusiastic and higher performing employees.  Some of the local population was not very nice and was judgmental when informed of my employer.

review_title: Great place to live and work
pros: Small town living environment, lots of outdoor activities. Great group of caring people who want you to succeed. Focused on providing skills necessary to get jobs after graduation.
cons: Funding questions are causing the administration to nickle and dime everything from parking to computer labs to road access. The IT department is an absolute nightmare to deal with, and they have recently decided to close most computer labs on campus. Not the way for a university who's slogan is "Create The Future" - How? With type writers???

review_title: Great athletic dept. to work in
pros: Good people who truly care about each other and act as if they're all a large family. Everyone is supportive of one another's sports and goals off the field.
cons: Being a primarily division II NCAA school, some of the funding is tough and the pay can be low but if you enjoy sports and want to wear a lot of hats and learn a lot, this could be the place for you!

review_title: Great place to study, great environment and community
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: The Michigan Tech campus is one of the most safe campus in US. During the summer time, it has lots of outdoor activities you can participate. The mechanical engineering major is pretty good. The people there are also very nice and friendly. Great place to study.
cons: The winter of Houghton is really long. The snow will keep falling for about 7 months a year. If you like snow, here is your heaven. But you won't like the several inches of snow on top of your car every morning and sometime blizzard.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Michigan tech has one of the best academic environment in the whole area, it provide quality education and right now I am very happy with my job. The people around are helpful and supportive. Working atmosphere is competitive and help to learn a lot
cons: Well, The salary is not satisfactory with the amount of hour you worked. The place is kind of remote and not much thing to do around. The winter is very cruel and nasty.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: If you love winter, Tech knows how to party with it. The community and heritage is great. If you like small towns, you'll know everyone there is to know within a year or so. The summers are some of the best in the country.
cons: Its a small town in the middle of nowhere so there usually isn't much to do after a year or so here. If you're really concerned about pay, Tech pays well for the very low cost of living in the area, but is still below average.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros:
The stipend paid for GTA's allows for comfortable living in the area without a financial struggle.  

MTU is situated in a beautiful area with vast amounts of nature to be explored in the offseason with many trails, parks, etc actually being owned and taken care of by MTU.
cons:
Location of MTU (Houghton, MI) is known for extremely cold winter months with some of the highest recorded snowfall in the country.

Additionally the city is fairly remote, with the nearest other large city being about two hours (one way) by car.

pros: It is a very low time commitment, and I have always gotten the hours I requested. Most of the time it is a low stress environment (it gets a little busier between classes). The coordinator was helpful and friendly. I enjoyed helping people with questions on the technology, because they were usually easy to fix.

pros: I worked as the Student Philanthropy Supervisor. I absolutely loved it. I had great co-workers and a great boss. It was an extremely positive environment. One of the best jobs I have ever had. It was also somewhere that (if you really wanted to stay), you could probably find some kind of advancement.
cons: The only con I could think of was that the hours were not flexible and I would have liked the opportunity to get more hours.

review_title: Great people, but often depends on who you know

cons: However, it also tends to be fairly insular. This is a small community - many staff members have known their colleagues since they were in diapers! So, it is important to build relationships whenever possible.

review_title: Run like a business, not a school
pros: Beautiful location.  I loved living in Houghton.  The area is beautiful, the campus is beautiful, and the opportunities on campus are good--arts, gym, ski slopes, etc.  Drive 15 minutes in any direction, and you hit a gorgeous lake.  Cost of living is low, and restaurant variety is exceptional, especially considering how remote it is.  There are at least three really exceptional Chinese restaurants in the area, representing different distinct culinary areas of China, something that I actually miss since I've moved away.
cons:
The school is run with an eye to profit rather than education.  
Administration will not have your back when faced with student issues.  The biggest problem is that they have no minimum TOEFL score to enter the university, so students who have enough money can come over with no English at all, thinking that they are going to be able to take classes.  The school is not up front with the students, so when the students get here and have to take 2+ years of exclusively ESL classes before they even begin on their major classes, they are understandably angry.  They expect a 4 year degree, and instead end up spending 6.  Some lose scholarships if they can't get through ESL quickly enough, and there's nothing we can do as instructors, once they're here, to make it more fair for them.

pros: good acadamic environment, and all staffs are very nice. Especially, summer is very comfortable. but the winter is a little bit long
cons: the traffic is not convenient. only 2 airflghts are available every day. the winter is a little bit long and the snow is very terrible

review_title: Great community and fun people in Housing and Residential Life
pros: The majority of the people you work with are really great and it's a really fun and open environment. You definitely get out of it what you put in.
cons: Sometimes the work takes over your life, but if you love your job maybe that's okay.

review_title: Great learning experience as a GRA
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Michigan Tech has a ton of experienced professors, faculty and staff.  They have both new and old equipment to learn on, and typically upgrade to the top of the line as it comes out.  The learning experience here is great, but it is like any education, you must apply yourself!
cons: Some times out of date equipment is used.

pros: Working as a student is a good way to earn money to pay for your classes, food, books, housing, etc. while you attend school.  Many employers on campus are willing to and have no problem working around your schedule.
cons: Working during college takes away time that you could be spending studying, doing research or homework, hanging out with friends, etc.

review_title: Michigan Tech is a wonderful place
pros: Michigan tech is filled with a lot of very caring people. The small town atmosphere of the Houghton area is a wonderful place to live. Smart students doing world class research makes it even better too!
cons: Michigan Tech is pretty isolated, and the winters can be bad. Also, there are few opportunities for advancement in the area.

review_title: Great place to learn while being able to finish my schooling.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Working in a group was the best thing, I also learned a lot of training in many backgrounds.
cons: There was not much negativity about this job, it was research up and downs are expected.

pros:
The Supervisors are fun
You get to play whatever music you want
The co-workers tend to be pretty cool.
cons:
The closing shift runs until about 1:30 am, which can make getting up for class hard.
Nobody likes working until 1:30 am.

pros: Stress free work environment that works with your class schedule. Most work days include, a good deal of "free time" to surf the web or work on homework.
cons: You usually don't get too many hours, so not great if you need lots of cash. The job can also get pretty boring if nobody is calling and nobody is coming in.

pros: Great way to influence future engineers and learn all that Tech has to offer! Great group of people to work with. Would recommend working the Summer Youth Programs if your currently a student looking for summer income and a great experiance.
cons: Jobs during the school year can be a bit difficult if your a full-time student but the University offers flexibility

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Good team work, great mentoring, new avenues to learn, good environment to work in, great support from colleagues, awesome facilities, good offices
cons: lots and lots of snow to tackle and less salary coupled with a huge amount of work. Food at the cafeteria is not great and I usually end up eating somewhere outside the campus

review_title: A good place to be a GTA while getting a MS
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Interview was easy, I learned a lot while teaching. It gave me valuable teaching experience. I got to know some other grad students that I wouldn't have met otherwise. The job wasn't difficult, and also not boring.
cons: Payroll got a little confusing occasionally, but it was always quickly sorted out.

review_title: Good place to study and to do research.
pros:
Located in a quiet city (Houghton), so there is little lure or disturbance to your work and life. 
People here are friendly and relatively pure-hearted.
cons:
Far from big cities, thus deficient of job opportunities.
Poor small town for girls who like shopping.
Very much snow in winter.

review_title: International Graduate Teaching Assistants Assistance Program (IGTAAP)
pros:
Great way to meet and learn from international students
Super flexible hours
Low supervision. You get to build your own lesson plan
Coworkers are great
cons: In the past, weekly staff meetings have been scheduled at odd times because of schedule misalignment among students workers. Really, not a con. Overall, a fantastic work environment.

review_title: Fun on-campus student job for those who like math.
job_title: Math Learning Center Coach in Houghton, MI
pros: Moderate to strong sense of student leadership and community. Relaxed atmosphere with plenty of opportunities to help fellow students improve.
cons: The majority of your hours are often dependent upon how many appointments you can happen to get. The number of students who book appointments is often unpredictable and insufficient.

pros:
Get to help people learn and debug
Smart and cool co-workers
Not too strict, and pretty flexible
cons: There's not really to much to complain about. In general, I like the job.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Porter Ranch, CA
pros: Relatively flexible working hours. Have opportunities to communicate with other students, and of course make friends.
cons: Pay rate is low. Lab curriculum needs to be constructed more friendly and relevant with regular calculus classes.

pros: Good atmosphere among students. People are nice and open to each other. Far from big cities and snowy winter make studying the only option for you.
cons: At the upper peninsular of MI. Economically not very advanced - no good job opportunities locally.

job_title: Digital User Experience Team Member in Houghton, MI
pros: Flexible Hours, beautiful location during the summer, good immediate leadership, project freedom once a project is given.
cons: Higher leadership can be inconsistent.  Tendency for nothing to get done in an immediate fashion when necessary.  Location is terrible during the winter, mostly due to inconsistent campus snow removal.

job_title: Research and Teaching Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Great bosses, rewarding and fun work, flexible hours, lot of learning opportunities
cons: None that I can think of except parking space. I was very satisfied in the numerous jobs I held there

job_title: Engineering Fundamentals LEAP Leader in Houghton, MI
pros: Great pay. Great networking opportunities.
cons: Changes take time but that’s to be expected anywhere.

pros: All of the jobs I've worked on campus have been really flexible about hours and covering shifts if you're unable to work. Everyone I work with is really nice, including supervisors.
cons: Only pays minimum wage, but some jobs have opportunities to earn more as you gain experience.

pros: Great training, fun environment, very flexible and lots of freedom to be creative on your tours.
cons: Terrible pay and terrible uniforms

review_title: Too much snow in this town
pros: People are really nice here. Nature is very pretty around this small town.
cons: The winter is too long... Too much snow... Low efficiency. Not good for research because this place is too remote to connect to the rest of the world.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: Very considerate and kind people to work with which made my stay at the end of world a unforgettable experience.
cons: Strenuous mental effort demanded but this will only make you stronger and better.

pros: Lots of variety, flexible working hours and very flexible in terms of time off
cons: Not conducive to career growth, extremely difficult to move up internally

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Houghton, MI
pros: It has a friendly environment. Plus, I love teaching in general. The person in charge of TAs is a disciplined veteran.
cons: The only thing is about the location: Isolated lo action far up in Upper Peninsula of Michigan, with wild winters.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Decent benefits here but declining yearly. Work schedule is okay. This used to be the place to work in the area. It is still the biggest employer here.
cons: Benefits decreasing yearly. Morale is dropping also.

pros: The department kept me on after graduating. A great place to be.
cons: This depends on the person, but the winters are quite long. I enjoyed the long winter, but many can't handle it.

pros:
Flexible shifts. Can work around class schedule. Student caterers get free food after every event.
If you are on bar tending duty, the tips are decent.
cons: None that I can think of.

working with very smart and intelligent people
great experience to build up career for engineers

cons: Poor Health Insurance is provided for GTA or GRAs.

review_title: good place to study and live
